key_insight: MemFlow introduces an adaptive, flowing memory mechanism that dynamically selects and compresses different historical cues for each upcoming video chunk, enabling consistent long-range video narratives without fixed, lossy summarization strategies.
problem_solved: Maintains content consistency across long streaming video generation by overcoming rigid, predefined memory-compression strategies that fail to provide the right historical cues for different to-be-generated segments.
method: Adaptive memory selection: before generating each new chunk, MemFlow identifies which historical frames or cues are most relevant and prioritizes them rather than applying a single global compression.
Flowing memory update: memory is updated as a dynamic stream (flow) so information useful for future chunks is retained or refined, enabling targeted retention of salient narrative elements.
Efficient representation: uses compact, task-aware memory encodings (e.g., learned tokens or selective features) to keep computation and storage low while preserving long-range consistency.
impact: Enables more coherent and scalable streaming video generation—practical for long-form video synthesis, real-time narrative continuations, and memory-constrained deployment—by improving consistency without large memory or compute overhead.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: show incoming video stream → adaptive memory selector → flowing memory store → generator (next chunk)
Before/after frame sequence: example comparing fixed-compression memory vs MemFlow outputs to highlight improved consistency
Memory attention map: heatmap visualizing which historical frames/cues are selected for different upcoming chunks
Efficiency chart: bars comparing memory footprint and latency for fixed-strategy vs MemFlow
paper_title: MemFlow: Flowing Adaptive Memory for Consistent and Efficient Long Video Narratives
paper_authors: Sihui Ji, Xi Chen, Shuai Yang, Xin Tao, Pengfei Wan
